sentence4: NOTE: A child in a rear-facing child passenger restraint system may not ride in the front seat of an airbag-equipped vehicle.
sentence5: -Children who are under 8 years old, or who are less than 4 feet 9 inches tall: Secure in a child passenger restraint system in a rear seat. In some cases, children under 8 years old may ride in the front seat of a vehicle in a federally-approved child passenger restraint system. They may ride in the front seat if:
sentence6: -There is no rear seat.
sentence7: -The rear seats are side-facing jump seats.
sentence8: -The rear seats are rear-facing seats.
sentence9: -The child passenger restraint system cannot be installed properly in the rear seat.
sentence10: -All rear seats are already occupied by children 7 years old or younger.
sentence11: -Medical reasons prevent the child from riding in the back seat.
sentence12: -Children who are 8 years old or older, or at least 4 feet 9 inches tall: May use a properly secured safety belt that meets federal standards.
sentence13: Your local law enforcement agency or fire department can check the installation of your child passenger restraint system. As your child grows, check that the child passenger restraint system is the right size.

sentence2: Air bags are a valuable safety feature on many vehicles. They can help keep you safer than a seat belt alone.
sentence3: Ride at least 10 inches from the airbag cover, as long as you can maintain full control of your vehicle. Measure from the center of the steering wheel to your breastbone. Contact your vehicle dealer or manufacturer  if you cannot safely sit 10 inches away from the air bag. They may have
sentence4: advice about additional ways to move back from your air bag. Passengers should also sit at least 10 inches away from the passenger-side air bag.
sentence5: NOTE: Children seated next to a side air bag may be at risk of serious or fatal injury.

sentence2: It is illegal to leave a child who is six years old or younger unattended in a vehicle. A child may be left under the supervision of a person who is at least 12 years old.
sentence3: It is dangerous and illegal to leave children or animals in a hot vehicle. The temperature inside a parked vehicle can rise rapidly when it is sitting in the sun. This is true even if a window is left slightly open. Too much exposure to heat can lead to dehydration, heat stroke, and death.

sentence2: In California, you may never drive faster than is safe for the current road conditions. This is known as the Basic Speed Law.
sentence3: Make sure you manage your speed and slow down when conditions call for it. Regardless of the posted speed limit, your speed should depend on:
sentence4: -The number of vehicles on the road.
sentence5: -The speed of other vehicles on the road.
sentence6: -The road surface: smooth, rough, graveled, wet, dry, wide, or narrow.
sentence7: -Bicyclists or pedestrians on or crossing the road.
sentence8: -Weather: rain, fog, snow, wind, or dust.
sentence9: -Traffic congestion: small changes in your driving habits can help reduce congestion. Avoid weaving in and out of freeway lanes.
sentence10: There are also situations with specific speed limit laws and conditions where you should reduce your speed. Unless otherwise posted, the ideal maximum speed limit on most California highways is 65 mph. It is 55 mph on a two-lane undivided highway and for vehicles towing trailers.

sentence2: Sometimes dangers will be on both sides of the road at the same time. For example, parked cars to the right and oncoming cars to the left.
sentence3: If one danger is greater than the other, give more space to the most dangerous situation. Suppose you are on a two-lane road with an oncoming vehicle to the left and a bicyclist ahead to your right. Instead of driving between the vehicle and the bicyclist, take one danger at a time. Slow down and let the oncoming vehicle pass. When the vehicle has passed, move to the left to allow plenty of space (at least three feet) to pass the bicyclist. If there is a steady flow of oncoming vehicles, use as much of the left lane as you safely can to pass the bicyclist.

sentence2: If you have a tire blowout or accelerator malfunction:
sentence3: 1.Turn on your emergency flashers.
sentence4: 2.Hold the steering wheel tightly and steer straight ahead.
sentence5: 3.Slow down gradually by taking your foot off the accelerator slowly.
sentence6: -If your accelerator is stuck, shift to neutral and apply your brakes.
sentence7: -If you cannot shift to neutral, you should shut off the engine to initiate the vehicle slowing. DO NOT remove the key from the ignition.
sentence8: 4.Let the vehicle slow to a stop, completely off the road.
sentence9: 5.Fully apply the brakes when the vehicle is almost stopped.

sentence2: If your wheels drift off the pavement:
sentence3: 1.Grip the steering wheel firmly.
sentence4: 2.Remove your foot from the accelerator.
sentence5: 3.Brake gently.
sentence6: 4.Check for traffic behind you.
sentence7: 5.Carefully steer back onto the pavement.
sentence8: Do not pull or turn your steering wheel with too much force. This may cause you to drive into oncoming traffic.

sentence2: In extreme heat, you should:
sentence3: -Watch the temperature gauge.
sentence4: -Avoid driving at high speeds for long periods.
sentence5: -Turn off the air conditioner.
sentence6: In extreme cold, you should:
sentence7: -Watch the temperature gauge. The engine may not have the correct level of antifreeze.
sentence8: -Use the defroster or slightly open your windows to keep them from fogging up.
sentence9: NOTE: See the vehicle owner's manual for more information.

sentence1: If Your Vehicle Becomes Disabled on the Freeway
sentence2: If your vehicle stops working on the freeway:
sentence3: 1.Safely pull over to the right shoulder.
sentence4: 2.Exit on the right side so you are away from traffic if you must get out of the vehicle.
sentence5: 3.Dial 511 from your cell phone or locate call box for assistance..
sentence6: 4.Return to your vehicle as soon as you can. Get back into the vehicle from the right side (away from traffic).
sentence7: 5.Stay inside your vehicle with your seat belt on until help arrives.
sentence8: 6.Use your emergency flashers at your discretion. They can help other vehicles see you at night and in different weather conditions.

sentence1: There are certain circumstances where it is safer to get out of your vehicle and stay away.
sentence2: These include situations where there is:
sentence3: -Not enough space on the shoulder.
sentence4: -A guardrail.
sentence5: -An area for you to safely stay away from freeway lanes.

sentence1: California Highway Patrol (CHP) Freeway Service Patrol (FSP)
sentence2: During commute times, the CHP FSP provides free emergency roadside services in certain areas. If you get stuck on the freeway because your vehicle stops running, FSP will:
sentence3: -Provide a gallon of gas if you run out.
sentence4: -Jump start your vehicle if the battery is dead.
sentence5: -Refill your radiator and tape hoses.
sentence6: -Change a flat tire.
sentence7: -Report a collision to CHP.

sentence1: If FSP cannot start your vehicle, they will have it towed (free of charge) to a CHP-approved location. CHP will notify an auto club or towing service.
sentence2: FSP will not:
sentence3: -Tow your vehicle to a private repair service or residence.
sentence4: -Recommend tow service companies or repair and body shops.
sentence5: -Tow motorcycles.
sentence6: -Help vehicles which have been involved in a collision, unless they are directed to by CHP.

sentence1: Call 511 for FSP information and assistance.
sentence2: Disabled Vehicles on Railroad Tracks If your vehicle stalls or stops while blocking part of a train track with a train approaching and warning lights flashing:
sentence3: -Immediately exit your vehicle. Run away from the tracks diagonally in the direction the train is coming from. Then call 911.
sentence4: If you do not see a train approaching and warning lights are not flashing:
sentence5: -Exit your vehicle. Dial the number located on the railroad crossing posts or metal control box near the tracks. Provide the crossing number (if posted). Tell them a vehicle is on the tracks. Then call 911.

sentence2: Avoid distractions while you drive. Some common distractions are:
sentence3: -Looking at a phone, navigation system, children, and pets.
sentence4: -Changing music or volume.
sentence5: -Applying makeup or shaving.

sentence2: Cell phones are the main source of distracted driving. Driving while using a handheld cell phone is unsafe and illegal.
sentence3: Adult drivers should only use a cell phone in hands-free mode when necessary.
sentence4: -Do not answer your cell phone if it rings. Let the call go to voicemail.
sentence5: -Do not send or read text messages or emails while driving.
sentence6: -Mount your cell phone on the windshield, dashboard, or center console. It cannot block your view of the road.
sentence7: -Use the single swipe or touch feature on the mounted cell phone.

sentence2: It is against the law for a minor to use a cell phone or electronic wireless device to answer calls and send or respond to text messages while driving.
sentence3: EXCEPTION: Minors may use a cell phone to make a call for emergency assistance.
sentence4: Be Familiar with New Technology
sentence5: The technology in vehicles is always advancing. We will see more self- driving vehicles and vehicles with advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS) on the road. Vehicles with these systems may respond to road situations differently than a human driver would.

sentence2: All gas-powered vehicles produce carbon monoxide. Carbon monoxide is a deadly odorless gas released from a vehicle's exhaust pipe. Never start your vehicle inside the garage with the door closed. Symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning include:
sentence3: -Tiredness
sentence4: -Yawning
sentence5: -Dizziness
sentence6: -Nausea
sentence7: -Headache
sentence8: -Ringing in the ears
sentence9: If you are experiencing any of these symptoms, have your exhaust system checked.

sentence2: California's driving under the influence (DUI) laws apply to both alcohol and drugs. It is illegal to drive while under the influence of alcohol or any drug that affects your ability to drive safely. As you age, your tolerance  to alcohol decreases, which increases the risk of alcohol-related driving problems. The law does not see a difference between illegal drugs and medications you get from a doctor or pharmacy. They can all affect your ability to drive safely and react to what you see and hear.
sentence3: No matter what age you are, it is illegal to drive after:
sentence4: -Drinking excessive amounts of alcohol in any form. This includes medications like cough syrup.
sentence5: -Taking any drug that affects your ability to drive. This includes prescriptions or over-the-counter medications.
sentence6: -Using any combination of alcohol or drugs that decreases your ability to drive safely.

sentence2: If you are 13 to 20 years old and convicted of operating a bicycle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs, your driving privilege may be suspended or delayed for one year once you are eligible to drive.
sentence3: Make sure you read medication labels and know the effects of any drug you use. If a law enforcement officer thinks you are driving while under the influence of drugs or alcohol, they have the right to ask you to take a blood or urine test. If you refuse to take one, DMV will suspend or revoke your driving privilege.

sentence1: Use or Possession of Alcohol or Cannabis Products in a Vehicle
sentence2: The law is very strict about carrying alcohol or cannabis products in your vehicle with you. It is illegal to drink any alcohol, to smoke or eat a cannabis product while you are driving or riding as a passenger in  a vehicle. If you are carrying any alcohol, cannabis in your vehicle, the container must be sealed and unopened. If it is open, you must keep the container in the trunk or place where passengers do not sit. It is also illegal to keep an open container of alcohol in your glove box. This law does not apply if you are a passenger in a bus, taxi, camper, or motorhome.
When you consume alcohol, traces of it enter your bloodstream. Your BAC measures how much alcohol is present in your bloodstream.
sentence3: It is illegal for you to drive if you have a BAC of:
sentence4: -0.08% or higher if you are over 21 years old.
sentence5: -0.01% or higher if you are under 21 years old.
sentence6: -0.01% or higher at any age if you are on DUI probation.
sentence7: -0.04% or higher if you drive a vehicle that requires a commercial driver's license.
sentence8: -0.04% or higher if you are driving a passenger for hire.
sentence9: If you drive with an illegal BAC, a law enforcement officer can charge you with DUI. Even if your BAC is below legal limits, that does not mean it is safe for you to drive. Almost everyone feels negative effects of alcohol, even at levels lower than the legal limit. Depending on how badly you are impaired, you may be arrested and convicted of a DUI even without a BAC measurement.
sentence10: The table below shows BAC estimates based on how many drinks are consumed, gender, and body weight. Remember, even one drink can affect your ability to drive safely.

sentence2: Subtract 0.01% for each 40 minutes that lapse between drinks. 1 drink = 1.5 oz. 80 proof liquor, 12 oz. 5% beer, or 5 oz. 12% wine. Fewer than 5 persons out of 100 will exceed these values.
sentence3: NOTE: It is illegal to drink alcohol or take drugs when you are operating a boat, jet ski, water skis, aquaplane, or similar vessels. Learn more in the California Harbors and Navigation Code.

sentence2: When you drive in California, you consent to a breath, blood, or urine test if a law enforcement officer suspects you of DUI. If you agreed to take a preliminary alcohol screening (PAS) or breath test, you may still be required to take a blood or urine test to detect the presence of drugs. If you refuse, DMV will suspend or revoke your driving privilege. If you are arrested for DUI:
sentence3: -California's Administrative Per Se law requires DMV to suspend your driving privilege.
sentence4: -The law enforcement officer may take your driver's license and give you a temporary driver's license for 30 days.
sentence5: -You may request a DMV administrative hearing within 10 days from the date of your arrest.

sentence2: If you are convicted of a DUI, DMV will suspend or revoke your driving privilege and you:
sentence3: -Must complete a DUI program.
sentence4: -Must file SR 22/SR 1P.
sentence5: -Must pay any applicable license reissue or restriction fees.
sentence6: -May be required to install an ignition interlock device (IID) on your vehicle.

sentence1: Here are some additional penalties if you are convicted of DUI:
sentence2: -You may be sentenced to up to six months in jail.
sentence3: -You may have to pay a fine.
sentence4: -Law enforcement may impound your vehicle and you may have to pay a storage fee.
sentence5: -If you cause serious injury or death while driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol, you may face civil lawsuits.
sentence6: All DUI convictions remain on your driver's record for 10 years. If you get any other DUIs during that time, the court or DMV may give you an additional penalty.

sentence2: If you are under 21 years old, there are additional laws for possessing and consuming alcohol.

-You may not carry any alcohol beverage inside a vehicle unless an individual who is 21 years old or older is with you. The container must be full, sealed, and unopened. If opened, the alcohol must be kept in the trunk or place where passengers do not sit.
sentence3: EXCEPTION: If you are working for someone with an off-site liquor sales license, you may carry alcoholic beverages in closed containers.
sentence4: -If you are caught with alcohol in your vehicle, law enforcement can impound your vehicle for up to 30 days. The court may fine you and suspend your driver's license for one year. If you do not already have a driver's license, the court may ask DMV to delay giving you your first driver's license for up to one year.

sentence2: -If a law enforcement officer suspects you of consuming alcohol,   they can require you to take a hand-held breath test, PAS, or another chemical test.
sentence3: -If you are convicted of a DUI with a BAC of 0.01% or higher, DMV may
sentence4: revoke your driving privilege for one year. You must also complete a licensed DUI program.
sentence5: -If your PAS shows a BAC of 0.05% or higher, the officer may require you to take a breath or blood test.
sentence6: -If a later test shows you have a BAC of 0.05% or higher, you may be arrested for a DUI and your driving privilege may be suspended.

sentence1: Financial Responsibility, Insurance Requirements, and Collisions
sentence2: You must have your proof of financial responsibility (insurance) when you drive and for a drive test. If you get into a collision, you must show proof to the other drivers involved in the collision.
sentence3: Insurance Requirements
sentence4: Your insurance must cover at least:
sentence5: -$15,000 for a single death or injury.
sentence6: -$30,000 for death or injury to more than one person.
sentence7: -$5,000 for property damage.
sentence8: Parents or guardians take on financial responsibility for drivers younger than 18 years old and pay for damages if the driver is involved in a collision. Drivers who are 18 years old and older take on their own financial responsibility.
sentence9: Before you buy insurance, make sure that the agent, broker, or insurance provider is licensed by the California Department of Insurance. For more information,   visit   insurance.ca.gov/license-status/.

sentence2: If you cannot afford liability insurance, you may be eligible for the California Low Cost Automobile Insurance Program. For more information, visit mylowcostauto.com or call 1-866-602-8861.
Understand factors that lead to collisions so you can try to avoid them.
The most common causes of collisions are:
sentence3: -Driver distractions.
sentence4: -Unsafe speed.
sentence5: -Improper turns.
sentence6: -Not following the right-of-way rules.
sentence7: -Not following stop signals and signs.
sentence8: -Driving on the wrong side of the road.
sentence9: -A vehicle traveling faster or slower than the flow of traffic.
sentence10: If you see a vehicle's emergency flashers ahead, slow down. There may be a collision or other road emergency. Pass carefully.
sentence11: Avoid driving near collisions, if possible. If anyone is injured, they will get help faster if other vehicles are not blocking the road.

sentence1: What to Do if You Are in a Collision
sentence2: If you are in a collision:
sentence3: -You must stop. Someone could be injured and need your help. Failing to stop or leaving the scene of an accident is called a hit-and-run.  The punishment is severe if you are convicted of a hit-and-run.
sentence4: -Call 911 right away if anyone is hurt.
sentence5: -Move your vehicle out of traffic if no one is hurt. Then call 911.
sentence6: -Show your driver's license, vehicle registration card, insurance information, and current address to the other driver, law enforcement officer, and anyone else involved in the collision.
sentence7: -You must make a report to law enforcement within 24 hours of the collision if anyone is injured or killed. Your insurance agent, broker, or legal representative can also file the report.
sentence8: -Try to find the owner if your vehicle hits or rolls into a parked car or other property. If you cannot find the owner, leave a note with your name, phone number, and address. Securely attach the note to the vehicle or property. Report the collision to law enforcement.
sentence9: -If you kill or injure an animal, call the nearest humane society or law enforcement. Do not try to move an injured animal.

sentence2: If you are in a collision, you must report it to DMV within 10 days if:
sentence3: -The collision caused more than $1,000 in damage to property.
sentence4: -Anyone was injured or killed. This applies even if the injuries were minor.

sentence2: Each driver must file a Report of Traffic Accident Occurring in California (SR 1) with DMV at dmv.ca.gov/accidentreport. You (or  your representative) must file a report whether or not you caused the collision. This applies even if the collision happened on private property.
sentence3: Your driving privilege will be suspended if you fail to file a report. Law enforcement will not make a report for you.

sentence2: Your driving privilege will be suspended for up to four years if you are in a collision and do not have proper insurance coverage. It does not matter who was at fault.
sentence3: You can get your driver's license back during the last three years of the suspension if you provide a California Insurance Proof Certificate (SR 22/SR 1P) and maintain it during the three-year period.
sentence4: Collisions on Your Driver's Record
sentence5: If you are involved in a collision resulting in $1,000 in damage, or where anyone is injured or dies, it is your responsibility to report the collision to DMV. DMV will add it to your driver's record. It does not matter who caused the collision.

sentence2: You need to register your vehicle in California to use it in the state. For more information, visit dmv.ca.gov/vrservices.
When you buy a vehicle, you have 10 days to transfer ownership to your name.
sentence3: When you sell a vehicle, you must notify DMV within five days by completing a Notice of Transfer and Release of Liability at dmv.ca.gov/nrl.

sentence2: You have 20 days to register your vehicle after you become  a resident or get a job in California. For more information, visit dmv.ca.gov/outofstatevr.
sentence3: All vehicles registered in California are required to meet California requirements including vehicle emission controls in support of California's clean air standards. DMV cannot register a vehicle if it does not qualify.

sentence2: Eventually, every driver will need to evaluate and assess their driving skills and abilities. If you are concerned about your driving, ask a trusted driver with a valid driver's license to sit in the passenger seat and observe your driving. Your observer should note any dangerous driving behaviors and give suggestions for improvement. Listen carefully and apply what you have learned. Consider professional driving lessons or driving classes as an alternative.
The Vehicle Code allows DMV to investigate and reexamine every driver's ability to operate a motor vehicle safely. A physical or mental condition
sentence3: or poor driver's record can be the basis for a reexamination, not a driver's age. Drivers with a physical or mental condition can be referred to DMV by a physician, law enforcement, or family member by submitting a completed Request for Driver Reexamination form.
sentence4: Cognitive disorders, such as dementia, seizure disorder, brain tumor, Parkinson's disease, stroke, or vertigo, present a significant challenge to safe driving. Individuals suffering from these conditions may lose their ability to drive safely.
sentence5: NOTE: When a referral or diagnosis for someone with a mild cognitive impairment is received by DMV, the Driver Safety team will schedule  a reexamination. For more information regarding the reexamination process, visit dmv.ca.gov/reexamination.

sentence2: -Request medical information from you or your physician.
sentence3: -Conduct an in-person or over the telephone reexamination.
sentence4: -Require you to take a knowledge, vision, or driving test(s).
sentence5: -Issue you a limited term driver's license.
sentence6: -Immediately suspend or revoke your driving privilege if your physical or mental condition presents an immediate threat to public safety.
sentence7: -Take no action against your driving privilege.

sentence2: DMV places restrictions on a driver's license to ensure a driver is operating a vehicle within their ability. Restrictions may be imposed by DMV or required by law. Restrictions placed on your driving privilege will be reasonable and necessary for your safety and the safety of others.
sentence3: Restrictions and conditions may include:
sentence4: -Requiring a driver to place special mechanical devices on their vehicle, such as hand controls.
sentence5: -Limiting when and where a person may drive, such as no night or freeway driving.
sentence6: -Requiring eyeglasses or corrective contact lenses.
sentence7: -Requiring additional devices, such as outside mirrors.
sentence8: NOTE: There are no specific restrictions for seniors. All restrictions are based on conditions, not age.
sentence9: Any restriction placed on your driver's license is based on the examiner's findings and recommendations.

sentence2: Senior drivers often have unique needs and concerns about driving. Driving requires certain physical, visual, and mental abilities. We all want to continue driving as long as we can. However, the time may come when we must limit or stop driving temporarily or permanently. Here are some warning signs of an unsafe driver:
sentence3: -Getting lost in familiar places.
sentence4: -Dents and scrapes on the car, fences, mailbox, garage doors, etc.
sentence5: -Frequent close calls or collisions.

sentence2: -Limiting or not driving at night.
sentence3: -If night driving is necessary, choose a well-lit route.
sentence4: -Driving during the time of day when traffic is light.
sentence5: -Avoiding difficult intersections.
sentence6: -Driving for short distances or limiting driving to essential places.
sentence7: -No freeway driving.
sentence8: -Installing an additional right-side mirror.

sentence1: Terms you must be aware of:
sentence2: Blood alcohol concentration (BAC): Your BAC is the amount of alcohol in your blood. For example, if your BAC is 0.10%, that means you have 0.10 grams of alcohol in 100 milliliters of blood.
sentence3: Driving performance evaluation (DPE): DPE is the portion of the behind-the-wheel drive test when you drive your car with a DMV examiner who evaluates your driving skills.
sentence4: Pedestrian: A pedestrian can also be a person with a disability using a tricycle, quadricycle, or wheelchair for transportation.
sentence5: Right-of-way: Helps determine who is allowed to go first in situations where vehicles, pedestrians, and cyclists meet on the road.
sentence6: Three-second rule: A driving rule that helps you estimate how closely you should follow other vehicles. When the vehicle in front of you passes a certain point, such as a sign, count three seconds. If you pass the same point before you finish counting, you are following too closely.
sentence7: Traffic citation: Also known as a ticket, a traffic citation is an official summons issued by law enforcement for violating a traffic law.
sentence8: Vulnerable road users (VRU): VRUs are non-motorized road users, such as cyclists, pedestrians, and persons with disabilities or reduced mobility and orientation using a wheelchair, tricycle, or quadricycle.
sentence9: Yield: Yield means to wait for, slow down, and be ready to stop (if necessary) to allow other vehicles or pedestrians who have right-of-way to proceed.
sentence10: Behind-the- wheel drive test: A drive test where you have control of the vehicle and are accompanied by a DMV examiner who is evaluating your driving skills.
